title: Kettleshulme Walks

images.title: Roger May, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking Down on Kettleshulme. Not an airborne camera shot, but this view from the slopes of Reed Hill by Higher Lane could give that impression. Judging by the contour lines on the O/S map, the viewpoint is some 150 metres higher than the view. Looking almost due East.

images.title: Sundial in Kettleshulme by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sundial in Kettleshulme. A village scene.

images.title: The Swan Inn, Kettleshulme by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Swan Inn, Kettleshulme

images.caption: Windgather Rocks

images.title: Pym Chair and heather moorlands by Peter Barr, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.caption: Fernilee Reservoir

description: This Cheshire based village sits close to the border with Derbyshire in the valley of the Todd Brook in the Pennines. The village is surrounded by a photogenic, undulating landscape of limestone and gritstone. It's a popular area for walkers with several local reservoirs and the splendid Lyme Park just a few miles to the north. This circular walk from the village takes you to some of the local walking highlights including the viewpoints at Windgather Rocks and Pym Chair. You'll then go on to enjoy the waterside trails at Errwood Reservoir and Fernilee Reservoir. The reservoirs lie just to the south east of the village in the beautiful valley of the River Goyt. To continue your walking around Kettleshulme you could head west to pick up the Gritstone Trail and follow it north to visit Lyme Park. The park includes resident deer, lakes, woodland trails, an historic house and hill climbs with some wonderful views towards Manchester.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Swan Inn is a great place for rest and refreshments after your walk. The historic pub dates back to the 15th Century and includes timber beams and an open log fire in Winter. There are two outdoor patio areas for warmer weather. You can find them at postcode SK23 7QU. They also provide car parking and are dog friendly.
